The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that he had had a letter from Miss Rathbone, M.P., suggesting that the Govern-ment might be able to say more in private about the recent conference on Refugees than it had been possible for them to say we the public debate on the 19th May, and asking whether he would receive for this purpose a deputation of Members of both Houses ofParliament. It was difficult for him, as leader of the House, torefuse to see Members of Parliament, but there was little more that could be said at this stage in view of our understanding with theUnited States Government that decisions resulting from theConference would not be disclosed in independent announcementsby either of the two Governments.The general feeling of the War Cabinet was that it was unreasonable that a request for a deputation to be received shouldbe made so soon after the matter had been fully debated in Parlia-ment. The best line for the Secretary of State for Foreign affairs to take would probably be to suggest that the deputation should atleast be postponed until Mr. Law had returned to this country.Offices of the War Cabinet, S.
